Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Michael Trenary of the University of Illinois at Chicago to conduct experimental work looking at the catalytic hydrogenation of molecules on metal alloy surfaces. These reactions are important in industrial as well as in organic synthesis applications. The particular metal catalysts that the Trenary group is looking at have a small amount of an expensive metal alloyed with the surface of an inexpensive metal. The ultimate goal of research like this is to obtain catalysts that have the same effectiveness as more expensive catalysts at much lower cost. The graduate and undergraduate students, many from underrepresented groups, working on this project will receive training in ultrahigh vacuum science methods, while working on societally-important chemical problems with very broad impact. Prof. Trenary begins a new collaboration with Olive-Harvey College, a Chicago-area college with a predominantly African-American student body, providing Olive-Harvey undergraduates with the opportunity to do research in his laboratory.

Professor Michael Trenary and his research group will use reflection/adsorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS) to monitor the reactivity of simple molecules adsorbed to a metal surface that has been modified (alloyed) with a small amount of a catalytically active metal. The RAIRS experiments will include time dependent studies designed to measure activation energies of elementary reaction steps and in situ studies at elevated hydrogen pressures designed to maintain hydrogen surface coverages at the temperatures where the hydrogenation reactions occur. The metal systems to be studied include Pd-Cu(111) and Pt-Ru(0001). Reactions to be studied include the hydrogenation of acrolein, the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene, the hydrogenation of surface N atoms; and the hydrogenation of adsorbed CN to methane and ammonia. The work will take on an international dimension through collaboration with STM researchers at RIKEN in Japan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many metal surfaces can catalyze important chemical reactions. However, metals with the highest catalytic activity are often some of the rarest and most expensive elements, such as palladium (Pd) and platinum (Pt). The general goal of this grant was to gain new insights into the surface chemistry that occurs over model catalyst surfaces that minimize the use of platinum-group metals. In one set of studies, we used an atomically thin layer of Pt on the surface of the less costly element ruthenium. In another set of experiments, we studied a novel type of catalyst in which individual palladium atoms replace copper atoms in the topmost atomic layer of a copper surface. The later surface is an example of what is known as a single-atom-alloy (SAA). The development of SAAs is significant as it uses the absolute minimum amount of an expensive and rare element such as palladium to promote important catalytic processes. To gain insights into the molecular mechanisms that occur on the surfaces of these novel bimetallic catalysts, we employed the technique of reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS). Although we have used this technique for many years, during this grant period we implemented a method that exploits the polarization dependence of the interaction of infrared light with molecules on surfaces to study reactions in the presence of significant pressures of gas phase reactants and products.  Using s-polarized light, we obtained spectra of the gas-phase molecules only, whereas spectra obtained with p-polarized radiation contain features due to surface species and to gas-phase species. Upon subtracting the s-polarized spectra from the p-polarized spectra, we obtained spectra of the surface species only. As one example, we studied the partial hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene over a Pd-Cu(111) SAA surface. This is an important industrial process, as acetylene contamination must be removed from the ethylene feedstock used in polymer production. The most cost effective way of doing this is to simply convert acetylene to ethylene. However, most catalysts that are effective for acetylene hydrogenation to ethylene will further convert ethylene to ethane, which is obviously unacceptable. From the s-polarized spectra, we observed that gas phase acetylene is selectively hydrogenated to gas-phase ethylene without also producing any gas phase ethylene. By subtracting the s-polarized spectra from the p-polarized spectra, we found that the acetylene hydrogenation takes places in the presence of a carbonaceous layer on the metal surface. The results demonstrated that a small number of Pd atoms converts a Cu(111) surface, which is completely ineffective for hydrogenation reactions, into a highly selective hydrogenation catalyst.  The publication based on this study was one of 16 that acknowledge support on this grant.

The broader impacts from the previous grant period have been in three main areas: human resource development, including providing research opportunities for undergraduates, enhancing international cooperation, and professional service. Six students who were partially supported by this grant received their PhDs and are now employed by private companies. Several undergraduates participated in summer research and worked closely with the graduate students. Two of the graduate students, both female (Zhu Liang and Esin Soy), were able to travel to Japan to work at the Japanese national laboratory known as RIKEN. While at RIKEN, they made use of low temperature scanning tunneling microscopy to observe surface chemical reactions at the single-molecule level related to the reactions that we studied in our UIC laboratory. This grant enabled me to continue to promote greater appreciation and awareness by American scientists and institutions of the scientific research done in Japan. For example, I successfully nominated Dr. Maki Kawai for the Welch Award of the American Vacuum Society, which she received in 2016. This helped to raise the status and visibility of women scientists in Japan.
